turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: My father had farm land.  It was the only thing we owned of any value.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: And it now belongs to you, according to Baltus.  I heard him say it.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Only the heirs were killed.  Proof that the Horseman slaughters by assignment.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: But, if the farm is not mine, who stole it away?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: No one yet, far as I can tell.  It has gone intestate.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: In test... what?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Intestate.  Your farm... all the farms... they belong to no one.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What does it mean?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Often in such cases, property which has gone intestate legally passes to whomever the deceased was indebted to. And, who in this town is owed a great many debts?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Baltus Van Tassel.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Did your father take a loan?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Yes.  I rode with him on payment days.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: There is no Masbath here.  My father's loan papers are missing.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: There are none for Magistrate Philipse either.  "Paasch, James" "Pieter, Thomas" "Pos, William."

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: I was getting worried.  Who was it?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Lady Van Tassel.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What was she doing?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Something I really wish I had not seen. Never mind it.  Did you find the victims' loan agreements?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: No.  They are all missing.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: There are no other doors.  This is as far as she could have gone.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It is nothing.  She comes to read books, so her father will not find her.  It is absolutely nothing.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What books?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Fiction plays and novels.  Baltus does not approve.  Now, come.  It may not be long before Lady Van Tassel returns.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: But, sir... what books?  Where are they?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What now?  Where is she?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Things have become complicated. Katrina is at the mill.  Ride ahead, find her and bring her to meet me outside the church.  Find her at all costs.  Quickly.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: She's the one who controlled the Horseman, isn't she, sir?  Sir?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I need time for thinking.  Without you hanging on my coattails for a change.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Won't you change your mind, sir? What can I say to convince you?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Nothing.  To hell with this place and all the people here.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Why... why are you like this?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: You do not know all that has happened.  You cannot understand.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: This is farewell.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Take me with you.  There's nothing left for me here.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I cannot.  You should not worry.  Van Ripper and his wife will look after you.  They will.  You will be well cared for.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Climb up!

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Lady Van Tassel...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I know.  Hold on.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What can we do?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Take the reins.

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I doubt that's the end.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: How are you?

turns.speaker: YOUNG MASBATH
turns.text: Tired.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Forgive me, I didn't know.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I... I am looking for Baltus Van Tassel.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Did they tell?  It is something in the air so that dreams come to everyone.  According to the elders, an Indian prophet held powwows here before the land was taken, and spells cast then still linger to this day.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Do you often make a habit of sitting on strange men's beds?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You are horribly old-fashioned, aren't you?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Feel free to form your own opinion.  Though it appears you already have.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Well, I intended to apologize for the behavior of my friend Brom Van Brunt, but it seems I've made matters worse.  I'll leave you to your business.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Excuse me... I should apologize.  I, um... I... have no great love of...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Other people?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Small talk.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: It might have been more.  Might have been positively grand talk.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Is it me, or are you this nervous around all women?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Perhaps it is because your suitor's hands were recently very nearly wrapped around my throat.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: My suitor?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The massive fellow... Brom.  For someone you call "friend," he misplaces a good portion of jealousy.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: He has proposed to me twice.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Which may explain his temperament. To have asked twice means the answer was "no" at least once.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I've read a great deal about your New York City.  Do be a dear and tell me all about it.  Sounds like an extraordinary place to live a life.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Extra ordinary, yes.  But first, you tell me about the Headless Horseman.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Not all think it is the Horseman. Many say witches come from the Western Woods to steal skulls for their cauldrons.  Some believe a person in this very town kneels before Lucifer, offering death as tribute.  And, still others believe none of it.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Are you so superstitious?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: To call a person superstitious is to imply they fear magic, but not all magic is black.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: There is no such thing as magic.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Really?  Then... what is your rebuttal to those romantic poets claiming proof of magic in a rose at full bloom, or even in a teardrop?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Poets have silly notions about plants and bodily secretions.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You are funny.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You do not disturb me.  Please stay. Having trouble sleeping?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: May I ask... why do you cover your book that way?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You pay great attention to small things.  I hide these as I hide all my books.  Father would not approve, lest it were the Bible.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I, um... I have something to show you, if you have a moment.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: These scars.  How did you get them?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I have had them since childhood.  I cannot remember what from.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: It would be interesting to find out.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Here it is.  A bird on one side. His cage on the other.  Now, stare at it.  The bird seems to be in his cage.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Yes, he does.  May I try?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: He only appears to be inside the cage.  The point being...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You made this, and the drawings?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Yes, but listen.  The illusion is easily explained.  The eye retains each image, till they combine.  And yet, some would call this toy magic.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Don't you see why?  Look closely a moment.  Put your intellect aside.  Can't you see what is inexplicable?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Oh, you are hopeless.  May I keep it at least?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: If you want.  But...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Then, I also have a gift for you. True magic which even you will not be able to deny.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Thank you.  No.  Here...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I insist that you have it.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Very well.  But, it will only sit gathering dust.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: That would be a pity.  Those words might show you something you've never seen before.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You promised justice.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: If these are the random stalkings of a monster, what good am I?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: People have put their trust in you.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: They have done nothing of the sort.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Won't they still have that justice?  Or, was it a vain promise?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Why would you do such a thing?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: No stone may be left unturned.  It may appear harsh...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I have misjudged you I think.  I did not imagine you were so cruel.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: You are not regarding it in full. The Widow Windsor had been run through by a sword.  I followed the bloodless wound, a wound whose path I could not comprehend till I had seen the Horseman with my own eyes.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What are you on about?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The child she carried was eight months grown at least... near to birthing.  The sword had pierced its tiny heart exactly.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Must I hear this?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: There was no blind stabbing.  This singular thrust found its target omnipotently, as if the Horseman made certain the unborn child died with its mother.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: And this gives worth to butchery?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It was not butchery.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What is it then?  Scientific method? How can any of this matter in the slightest?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I have no solution for its meaning yet, but I could not just ignore it.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Take a lesson from Young Masbath's desires, Ichabod Crane.  He follows with you to avenge his father's death. That I understand.  But, what do you want?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: To avenge his father, and the others.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: But, why?  Tell me why.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You falter with your answer because you strive without putting the whole of your heart into it.  Can't you see? You'll bring dignity to the dead even if you have to chop them into little pieces to do it.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: If it had been surgery on a living person, done to save that person's life, you would not question it.  Not for a moment.  So, let me be the first to tell you, dear girl... on the other side of these sheltering mountains, a whole world has advanced beyond such plebeian thinking as yours.  And someday, no matter how much you fear it, that world will come to roust Sleepy Hollow out of its slumber.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Allow me some time.  I have spent every hour in the company of others. I need to be alone.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What troubles you?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: The things I said to you before... I was wrong to say them.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: No, actually, you were not.  Every word you spoke had truth in it.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What has happened?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Lady Van Tassel... she is your stepmother, isn't she?  She bears so little resemblance.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: She is not your birth mother, is she?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: No, but... why do you ask that?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What happened to your mother?  Is she still alive?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: She died.  Her lungs were diseased... two years ago.  What is this about?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Memories have come back.  I had them forgotten, and wish I could forget them again... but they are here now.  Lord, how I hate this place.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: If you want me to go, I will.  Do you want me to leave?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I... I do not know.  I no longer know what I think or what I feel.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: It is only me.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Katrina.  Why do you follow?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I apologize if I worried you.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: A woman should not be out alone in these woods.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: But, I am not alone, am I?  I only wished to see what you were up to, and...  To thank you.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Blood.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Just... keep where you are.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: My God... what has happened?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: He... he tries to take the heads... they will not pass.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Why is it every grave I open holds a new mystery inside?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: The skull is gone.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Yes.  I did notice that, thank you.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What... what are you doing... ?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I'm drawing bad blood from the wound.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What is so urgent?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Come with me.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I have been reading your journal. I'm sorry.  I found it too fascinating to resist.  I rode to catch up with you at the Notary, out of curiosity.  Before I found you though, I overheard what you were said.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It was you there?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: When... when you spoke father's name along with accusations, I could not believe it.  I had to hide these... at least till I could confront him myself.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: And, what did he say?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: He did not do these things.  If you knew him, you would realize...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What did he say, Katrina?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I have not been able to face him yet.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The loans give the land to your father. It does not matter survivors are still on their farms.  They could be thrown off... tomorrow... a year from now.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Yes, I have seen that, and I told you why I hid them.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What would you have me believe?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: If you think I am behind this, say it.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The name Van Tassel is blackened.  You share that name.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Call me a liar, then, and a murderess. Say it, out and out.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Katrina...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Speak the words, Constable.  What is stopping you?  What has happened to your ability to transcend sentimentality?

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: I do not know.  Away.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: The church.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: He moves too fast.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: His horse.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Ichabod...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Keep climbing.  I will follow...

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Quickly, close it.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: No.  Get to the crest of the roof and be ready to jump.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The blades will carry us to the ground. Face front and wait for me.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: I... I can't do this.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: We have no choice.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: You said yourself.  What mere man could have downed the Belltower?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It is a prime tenet of science, Philipse, that because one thing appears improbable does not mean you embrace the utterly fantastical.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Returning to the Western Woods?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Yes, actually.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Use caution.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Do you know... I think those are the first words I have heard from you my entire time here.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: As my husband says, a wife should be always like an echo, and at the same time, quite unlike an echo.  Like an echo, she should speak only when spoken to, and unlike an echo, should never try to have the last word, or, at least that is what he believes.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Excuse me, Lady Van Tassel... Katrina is not in her room.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: No.  She has gone out.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: She has taken the last of our grain to be milled.  You do have a background in the medical arts, don't you, Constable?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Very little.  I must be going...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It appears well.  It has already clotted.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Look closer.  Do you have anything to clean it with?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: It is fine.  Now, I must...

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: I know you saw me.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What... ?

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: You cannot kill what is already dead.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Let her go!

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Yes... yes.  I think I will...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Van Ripper.  Can you show where the body lay?

turns.speaker: VAN RIPPER
turns.text: I can show exactly.

turns.speaker: VAN RIPPER
turns.text: Here... in front of this oak, facing north.  Horrible...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: To the best of your recollection, where did the open wound fall?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: There was not much blood, was there?

turns.speaker: VAN RIPPER
turns.text: I didn't see none.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Van Ripper, turn the coach about!

turns.speaker: VAN RIPPER
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Turn around.  Now!

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Van Ripper... do you have a gun?

turns.speaker: VAN RIPPER
turns.text: Yes.  Here...

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Pardon.  You did not answer when I knocked.  Are we intruding?

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: You are from the Hollow?

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: In a way, yes.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The Lenape who lived in these woods... do you know him?  The Redman?  I should tell you... he has been murdered.

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: Leave me.  You are not welcome here.

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: I hear him.  He rides to the Hollow and back.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: The Horseman.  Yes.

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: Sit.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: Can you help?

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: You want to see into the nether world... I can show you.  Whatever you see, do not move or speak.  I will hold him.

turns.speaker: ICHABOD
turns.text: What... what are you doing?

turns.speaker: OLD CRONE
turns.text: Close your mouth!  Keep silent.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Lay still, Ichabod.  Do not move.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Doctor, he is awake.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: You... you are alive.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Am I?  Or, are you and Young Masbath dead along with me?

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: He rides tonight.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: Father saw you die.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: He saw me thrown... saw the Horseman looming over me as I fled.  Things I wanted him to see.  But, as long as I govern the Horseman, he cannot harm me.  Baltus did not stay enough to see that.  He ran as a coward, unfettered by my fate.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: Imagine my surprise, finding him on a liason with a common servant.  A girl who had apparently become his secret love.

turns.speaker: KATRINA
turns.text: No one will believe your lies, whore.

turns.speaker: LADY VAN TASSEL
turns.text: This whore will see your mouth shut forever very soon.  But... I am not going to kill you.  Not me...

turns.speaker: THIRD MAN
turns.text: Go home.

turns.speaker: YOUNG ICHABOD
turns.text: May I see my mother?

turns.speaker: THIRD MAN
turns.text: You do not want to be here.  Go home to your father.

turns.speaker: YOUNG ICHABOD
turns.text: She did not do it... please listen...

turns.speaker: THIRD MAN
turns.text: She is guilty.

turns.speaker: YOUNG ICHABOD
turns.text: No, sir, please... she is innocent...

turns.speaker: THIRD MAN
turns.text: She has confessed.

turns.speaker: YOUNG ICHABOD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: THIRD MAN
turns.text: She has admitted to her evil and signed a written confession.  Do you know what confession is?  All that is left for you now is to pray for her soul.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: All right then, I'll see y'all later. Karl you done a good day's work. They right about you. Scooter, he's gonna knock you out of a job if you're not careful. I'll see you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SCOOTER
turns.text: Wait up, I'll leave with you and lock up.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Karl, they's a blanket up in under that cot and soap in the bathroom to clean up with.  Now there's one more thing. The way we lock these doors at night, you can't get out. You didn't want to go anywhere, did you?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Scooter, did I tell about the two old boys pissin' off the bridge?

turns.speaker: SCOOTER
turns.text: I can't remember.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: There was these two old boys hung their peckers off of a bridge to piss, one old boy from California and one old boy from Arkansas. Old boy from California says, "Boy this water's cold." Old boy from Arkansas says "Yeah, and it's deep too."  Get it? That's a goodun.

turns.speaker: SCOOTER
turns.text: Yeah, that's a goodun. I believe you did tell me that one before. I've heard that a bunch. Long time ago.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, yeah it's a classic. You know, Karl, I got to thinkin' about it last night and it's just not Christian of me to not let you have a key. I mean you been in lockup so long, you don't need me keepin' you locked up. You need to come and go as you please. Here, take this key, it'll get you in and out that back door.  Them french fries good?

turns.speaker: SCOOTER
turns.text: I can go. You don't have to. You don't never go.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Goddamnit, Scooter, come on. Pardon my language, ma'am.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Thank ye.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Now it's minimal wage and there ain't nothin' but a army cot and a toilet back there.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: They say you're a whiz on fixin' lawn mowers and things.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I've tinkered around on 'em a little bit.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: We order from Dairy Queen at noontime usually. We can buy your lunch till you get on your feet a little.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I like them french-fried potaters.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah, me too.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I don't reckon.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: If it works out and all, maybe we'll get you a key so you can get out at night if you need to. See you later.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Yeah, they's good all right.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You got any money?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They give me fifty dollars when they turned me loose. I spent up some of it on ridin' the bus and eatin' french-fried potaters.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, I'm gonna pay you today for this comin' week, so you'll have some walkin' around money. When you get off this evenin' you better go buy some toothpaste and cleanin' up supplies to have back there. Some hard candy and some magazines. Somethin' to keep you busy at night.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'll let you off while it's still daylight.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Now, Karl, you sure you want to go stay with these folks? You're welcome to keep on stayin here. It's workin' out real good.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: That boy wants me to.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: All right then. I'll see you bright and early. How you comin' along on that garden tiller?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I fixed it. Hit's a workin' pretty good.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You done fixed it? I'll be damned. Scooter told me it couldn't be fixed. 'Course Scooter's about as shitless as one poor son-of-a-bitch can be. You done fixed it. I'll just be damned. See you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Hit ain't got no gas in it.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: See there. Thinks of the simplest thing first.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Thank ye.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Scooter, let's me and you go over to Dairy Queen and pick up a few things for lunchtime.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Hey Jerry, how it's goin'. Good to see you. Been a long time.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Good to see you, Bill. How's everybody doin'?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Aw, pretty good. Kids are drivin' me crazy and Phyliss is gonna put me in the poorhouse. Can't complain other than that. Wouldn't do any good if I did.  Do you know Scooter, Jerry?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: No, don't guess I do.  Scooter, good to meet you.  This is him, the one I talked to you about on the phone. Now like I said, I'll understand if you get nervous about it. I'm not gonna lie to you now, he did get in that trouble but then he was real young.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I remember it real well. Cut them folks to pieces. His mama one of 'em.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Don't look much like he could. You say he can fix a small engine like nobody's bidness.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: He's a regular whiz at it. That's all he did when he was a kid.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, I ain't scared of him workin' here. You know me. I'm a church goin' man. Forgivin' man. When your time's up the Lord's gonna come git you. You seared of him, Scooter?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That old man of his still livin' over there on Clark Street I believe.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: He won't have anything to do with him. Now you say it's all right for him to stay out here in the back?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Fine with me. If he steals anything, I'll take it out of your pocket anyway.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: He won't steal. I'm tellin' you he's a pretty good ol' boy. Keeps to himself.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, I've got a roomful of work for him to do. Can't get Scooter to do any of it.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Karl, come over here. I want you to meet your new boss.  This is Bill Cox, runs this place. Says you can work here and stay in the back.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Good to know you, Karl.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: How 'bout you, Jerry.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: How are you, Bill?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Doin' pretty good. Got a sick tiller here. What's got you down this way?

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Just thought I'd check on Karl and see if everything's working out.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, he's pretty quiet. Except for them rackets and breathin' things he does. Ain't threatened me with a killin' or anything.  But boy you couldn't of been more right about him fixin' things. That son of a bitch is a regular Eli Whitney on a lawnmower. Loves french fries. Eats four larges and don't even so much as belch. I'm proud to have him.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Is him stayin' here workin' out?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: He's gone to stayin' over with that Wheatley boy and his mama in their garage. I think that little boy adopted him damn near like a mascot. But he's got a key here to come and go as he pleases. Everything's worked out good.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: Can I see him?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: WOOLRIDGE
turns.text: I'll see you, Bill.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Okay, stop back by. Don't worry about your boy here, he's doin' good.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I was kindly wantin' somethin' or 'nother d'eat.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Well, what did you want?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You have any biscuits for sale?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Naw, we don't have biscuits.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Did you decide, sir?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What you got that's good to eat?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Well, I guess it's all good.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What do you like to eat here?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: French fries. I like to eat them pretty good.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: French-fried potaters.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: How much you want fer 'em? I'll get some of them I reckon.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Sixty for small and seventy-five for large.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Give me the big'uns.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: These dang things are heavy. Hard to carry, too.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What you got in there, warshing?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Ain't you got no mama and daddy to tend to it?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I got a mama, but she's at work over at Ben's Dollar Store. My daddy's dead.  He got hit by a train.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: How fer you going with them sacks full of warsh?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: About a half a mile I think it is.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I'll help you tote 'em if I don't give out first.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Okay. You don't have to though.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: My name is Frank Wheatley. What's your name?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Karl's my name.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: ... on the third day I washed her. She wasn't very clean. I got all the right spots. She was the first one I ever kept for any length of time, you see I get bored easily, I have a short attention span. I can't say she enjoyed her stay, although the washcloth in her mouth held in place by good duct tape kept any complaints to a minimum. I don't really like people who talk a lot. I like to do the talking. I guess that's why I'm so fond of you. You're so easygoing, although I do sense a little tension in you sometimes. By the way, how was it out there? Did you have any fun? Make any new acquaintances? Tell me what it was like.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: They was a boy. We made friends.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: I bet you did. I was never bent that way. I'm bent the other way. So, you liked it out there in the world.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: It's too big.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Well, it's not too big in here, is it?  I feel very generous today. I feel like listening. I'm sure you have plenty to tell me. And please bore me with the details.  ) Come on Karl, who did you kill? Was it the boy?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Don't say nothin' about that boy.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Hey Freddy, what's goin' on boy. I seen your pitcher in the paper for catchin' that big-ass bass.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yeah She was a big 'un. You ain't drunk drivin' are you Doyle?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I figured that. Well you better be careful with that cripple in the back. You'll throw him out. Looks like you got a wagonful.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: We run outta somethin' to drink. Goin' to the county line. You want to race?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You know better than that. We're on duty. Catch me in that Camaro next week one night.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Catch you later Freddy!

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Doyle, you're awful. You shouldn't be that way.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I ain't sayin' it's right. I'm just tellin' the truth. What was he in the nuthouse for?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He's just mentally retarded, I guess.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: He had of went nuts and did somethin'. They don't put you in there for just bein' a retard. They's retards all over the place that ain't in the nuthouse. Do you know, Frank?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Yeah, that's right, Frank, you better ask him. I mean, don't hurt his feelin's or anything, but it would be good to know. I'm sure it's nothin'. He seems real sweet.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You sure are hung up on people bein' sweet.  Speakin' of which, where's your girlfriend? I thought he was comin' by here for something.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He'll be here in a little while, he's takin' me to get an ice cream.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Ain't that the sweetest thing. What am I supposed to do about supper with you traipsin' around with that fag?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You're not crippled. Get in there and make somethin'.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Boy, ain't you somethin' else. Talkin' back and everything. It kinda makes me horny when you talk back.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Frank, why don't you go off and play in your room if Doyle's gonna talk nasty.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Let's go, Vaughan.  Frank, we'll be back in a little while. I'll bring you back somethin'. You're food's in the oven warmin' over.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: See, you made him somethin'. Hey Vaughan, I was just goin' on with you, jokin' around, buddy.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't let it get to you.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: I just feel sorry for the poor thing.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Who could eat with him settin' there makin' that goddamn racket with his throat.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He does make some funny noises.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You know what, by God?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You know what we ought to do tonight?

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Please Doyle, don't.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Have a damn party! Call Morris and them and get the band together and just party our asses off. I'd like to show that fuckin' Karl to the guys. They'd get a kick out of that. Don't you know they would.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Please don't. Not tonight. I'm not up for it. They always stay till mornin'. I'm just give out, Doyle.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You don't have to do anything but pour some potato chips in a bowl and bring beers out when we get low.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Well, it's on! We're gonna rock. Linda, call Vaughan. Tell him to get over here. I'd like him to be here. I owe him a good time.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: No Doyle. Vaughan don't want to come to a party with you.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Too late, Honey. Fooled you. Done called him. He'll be here.  Or I'll go get him. Come on Karl, I need you to help me ice down a tub of beer, you and Frank.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Okay ladies and gentlemen  or both. It's come to the time in our show when we like to introduce the band. Over here on lead guitar Mr. Randy Horsefeathers. Come on hit a hot lick, Randy.  Well, come on, y'all are supposed to clap now. Come on!

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: Karl, you better clap your hands or he'll just keep on.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: He don't want to Doyle. Don't go Vaughan if you don't want to. You'll wreck Doyle, you're drunk.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: But honey, I'll be good. I promise. I love you sweetie. I'm just tryin' to help these two be part of things.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I thought I told everybody to get out of my house. That includes cocksuckers and retards. Get off your asses and go.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: This is not your house, Doyle. This is my house and I'll say who stays and goes. You've got a house, why don't you go get one of your girlfriends and go home to it.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You know better than to talk like that when I'm hurtin'. Don't make me knock the piss out of you.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: You're not stayin' here tonight. Go get sober before you come back. I'm tired of my child seein' this. Now you get yourself straight or I'll lock your ass out of my life for good.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You know what I told you, you even think of leavin' me, I'll kill you dead as a doornail.

turns.speaker: LINDA
turns.text: That might be better than this.
